Description: Pottery amphora with ring base, rounded sides, short straight neck, thickened rim, and two vertical handels. Very micaceous orange brown clay, some lime inclusions, sandy surface, 2.5YR 6/8.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Sanctuary of Apollo (Naukratis), Well 97 (= Well 1)? or Well 96 (= Well 4)?
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology, Philadelphia. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

No scratched numbers on pot. Philadelphia record card records 235 and 97 as findspots. If the piece is identical with Petrie 1886, p. 44, pl. XVII.16 then the findspot would be well 96 (dated by petrie to the 6th to 4th century BC, but with clear Ptolemaic artefacts). In his Journal (1884-5, pp. 186-7) Petrie describes excavating a well lined with pottery rings in the Apollo sanctuary where "four perfect jars, evidently lost in drawing water" were found; in this case, the findspot should be Well 97, as Well 96 is located just outside the sanctuary temenos.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XVII, no. 16)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (IC.134)
